member.name: T:Bloomberglp.AppPortalApi.DataPersistence.ExtensibleDataObject
member.summary: Implements IExtensibleDataObject interface. All object that intend to support forward compatible data contracts have to inherit from this type.

remarks.para: It is not possible to inherit from any other implementation of this interface - API will refuse to serialize.

para.span: Round-tripping occurs when data passes from a new version to an old version
and back to the new version of a data contract.
Round-tripping guarantees that no data is lost. Enabling round-tripping makes
the type forward-compatible with any future changes supported by the data contract versioning model.
To enable round-tripping for a particular type, the type must derive from the ExtensibleDataObject class.
The class contains one property, ExtensionData (returning the ExtensionDataObject type).
The property stores any data from future versions of the data contract that is unknown to the current version.

member.name: P:Bloomberglp.AppPortalApi.DataPersistence.ExtensibleDataObject.ExtensionData
member.summary: CLR uses it to keep data that is not compatible with a target type.
member.value: The value used by CLR to keep data that is not compatible with a target type.

member.name: T:Bloomberglp.AppPortalApi.Data.Sql.DbConnectionStringBuilder
member.summary: Provides a simple way to create and manage the contents of connection strings used by the class.
member.remarks:
The connection string builder lets developers programmatically create syntactically correct connection strings using properties and methods of the class.
The connection string builder provides strongly typed properties corresponding to the known key/value pairs allowed by the database. Developers needing to create connection strings as part of applications can use the DbConnectionStringBuilder class to build and modify connection strings.

member.summary: The connection string containing the parameters for the connection

item.description:
Ticks - Use DateTime.Ticks
ISO8601 - Use ISO8601 DateTime format
JulianDay - Use JulianDay format

Yes/On/1 - Store GUID columns in binary form
No/Off/0 - Store GUID columns as text

Normal - Normal file flushing behavior
Full - Full flushing after all writes
Off - Underlying OS flushes I/O's

Y - Automatically enlist in distributed transactions
N - No automatic enlistment

True - Use connection pooling
False - Do not use connection pooling

True - Don't create the database if it does not exist, throw an error instead
False - Automatically create the database if it does not exist
{size in pages} - Limits the maximum number of pages (limits the size) of the database

True - Use the more compatible legacy 3.x database format
False - Use the newer 3.3x database format which compresses numbers more effectively

{time in seconds}
The default command timeout

Delete - Delete the journal file after a commit
Persist - Zero out and leave the journal file on disk after a commit
Off - Disable the rollback journal entirely

True - Open the database for read only access
False - Open the database for normal read/write access
The maximum number of connections for the given connection string that can be in the connection pool

member.summary: Provides context for persistence data operations.
member.remarks: Use and to get this class instance. It has an internal constructor.

member.name: M:Bloomberglp.AppPortalApi.DataPersistence.PersistenceContext.SaveData``1(System.String,``0)
member.summary: Persists an instance of type on the Bloomberg network.
member.param: The unique identifier of data blob within a given Namespace.
Reference to object that is being saved (can be be of value tape also).
member.typeparam: Type of object is being saved (see "Data serialization rules" bellow).

remarks.para: Data serialization rules.

list.item: Root object's (the one that is passed to PersistenceService.DefaultContext.SaveData<T>) type can only derive from or
Types of serialized property or field can be only of the following: primitive types, nested types of root type; array, list, dictionary of primitive types or root's nested classes.

What is getting serialized. By default public fields and properties (POCOs - plain old CLR objects). It can customized by using WCF data contract serializer attributes. Types Supported by the Data Contract Serializer (http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms731923.aspx).

member.exception: Root ID cannot be null.
Raised when data cannot be saved properly on the network.
Raised when data does not confirm to sterilization rules.

member.name: M:Bloomberglp.AppPortalApi.DataPersistence.PersistenceContext.GetData``1(System.String)
member.summary: De-serializes an instance of object from persistent storage.
member.param: The unique identifier of data blob within a given nameSpace
member.typeparam: Data type of de-serialized data. Type should be compatible with the type used to serialize data. See "Basic rules of type compatibility" bellow.
member.returns: Strongly typed data, that is de-serialized form a persistence storage.
member.exception: Root ID cannot be null.
Raised when data cannot be retrieved properly from the network.
Raised when data does not confirm to sterilization rules.

remarks.para: See for data serialization rules
Type compatibility rules:

list.item: Do not change properties/fields names.
Do not change properties/fields types.
Do not delete properties/fields.
Do not attempt to version data contracts by type inheritance.

Starting with the first version of a data contract, always inherit from to enable round-tripping. implements IExtensibleDataObject interface. See "Forward-Compatible Data Contracts" (http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms731083.aspx)
Use guidelines from MSDN's "Versioning When Schema Validation Is Not Required" (http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms733832.aspx).

member.name: M:Bloomberglp.AppPortalApi.DataPersistence.PersistenceContext.GetDataAsString(System.String)
member.summary: De-serializes an instance of object as raw JSON. Intended to be used for debugging, or when a type the data was serialized from does not exists or is not compatible with the original anymore.
member.param: The unique identifier of data blob within a given nameSpace
member.remarks: Internal format (JSON) subject to change in future versions!
member.returns: Internal object representation as string. Currently it is JSON.
member.exception: Root ID cannot be null.
Raised when data cannot be retrieved properly from the network.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Windows.Shell.Utility.UrlEncode(System.String)
member.summary: Encodes a URL string. Duplicated functionality from System.Web.HttpUtility.UrlEncode.
member.remarks: Duplicated from System.Web.HttpUtility because System.Web isn't part of the client profile. URL Encoding replaces ' ' with '+' and unsafe ASCII characters with '%XX'. Safe characters are defined in RFC2396 (http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2396.txt). They are the 7-bit ASCII alphanumerics and the mark characters "-_.!~*'()". This implementation does not treat '~' as a safe character to be consistent with the System.Web version.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Windows.Shell.DoubleUtilities
member.summary: DoubleUtil uses fixed eps to provide fuzzy comparison functionality for doubles. NOTE: FP noise is a big problem and using any of these compare methods is NOT a complete solution, but rather the way to reduce the probability of repeating unnecessary work.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Windows.Shell.DoubleUtilities.Epsilon
member.summary: Epsilon - more or less random, more or less small number.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Windows.Shell.DoubleUtilities.AreClose(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: AreClose returns whether or not two doubles are "close." That is, whether or not they are within epsilon of each other. There are plenty of ways for this to return false even for numbers which are theoretically identical, so no code calling this should fail to work if this returns false.
member.param: The first double to compare.
The second double to compare.
member.returns: The result of the AreClose comparision.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Windows.Shell.DoubleUtilities.LessThan(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: LessThan returns whether or not the first double is less than the second double. That is, whether or not the first is strictly less than AND not within epsilon of the other number. There are plenty of ways for this to return false even for numbers which are theoretically identical, so no code calling this should fail to work if this returns false.
member.param: The first double to compare.
The second double to compare.
member.returns: The result of the LessThan comparision.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Windows.Shell.DoubleUtilities.GreaterThan(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: GreaterThan returns whether or not the first double is greater than the second double. That is, whether or not the first is strictly greater than AND not within epsilon of the other number. There are plenty of ways for this to return false even for numbers which are theoretically identical, so no code calling this should fail to work if this returns false.
member.param: The first double to compare.
The second double to compare.
member.returns: The result of the GreaterThan comparision.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Windows.Shell.DoubleUtilities.LessThanOrClose(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: LessThanOrClose returns whether or not the first double is less than or close to the second double. That is, whether or not the first is strictly less than or within epsilon of the other number. There are plenty of ways for this to return false even for numbers which are theoretically identical, so no code calling this should fail to work if this returns false.
member.param: The first double to compare.
The second double to compare.
member.returns: The result of the LessThanOrClose comparision.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Windows.Shell.DoubleUtilities.GreaterThanOrClose(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: GreaterThanOrClose returns whether or not the first double is greater than or close to the second double. That is, whether or not the first is strictly greater than or within epsilon of the other number. There are plenty of ways for this to return false even for numbers which are theoretically identical, so no code calling this should fail to work if this returns false.
member.param: The first double to compare.
The second double to compare.
member.returns: The result of the GreaterThanOrClose comparision.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Windows.Shell.ComStream
member.summary: Wraps an IStream interface pointer from COM into a form consumable by .Net.
member.remarks: This implementation is immutable, though it is possible that the underlying stream can be changed in another context.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Windows.Shell.ComStream.#ctor(System.Runtime.InteropServices.ComTypes.IStream@)
member.summary: Wraps a native IStream interface into a CLR Stream subclass.
member.param: The stream that this object wraps.
member.remarks: Note: The parameter is passed by ref. On successful creation it is zeroed out to the caller. This object becomes responsible for the lifetime management of the wrapped IStream.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Windows.Shell.ManagedIStream
member.summary: Wraps a managed stream instance into an interface pointer consumable by COM.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Windows.Shell.ManagedIStream.#ctor(System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the ManagedIStream class with the specified managed Stream object.
member.param: The stream that this IStream reference is wrapping.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Windows.Shell.ManagedIStream.Clone(System.Runtime.InteropServices.ComTypes.IStream@)
member.summary: Creates a new stream object with its own seek pointer that references the same bytes as the original stream.
member.param: When this method returns, contains the new stream object. This parameter is passed uninitialized.
member.remarks: For more information, see the existing documentation for IStream::Clone in the MSDN library. This class doesn't implement Clone. A COMException is thrown if it is used.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Windows.Shell.ManagedIStream.Commit(System.Int32)
member.summary: Ensures that any changes made to a stream object that is open in transacted mode are reflected in the parent storage.
member.param: A value that controls how the changes for the stream object are committed.
member.remarks: For more information, see the existing documentation for IStream::Commit in the MSDN library.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Windows.Shell.ManagedIStream.CopyTo(System.Runtime.InteropServices.ComTypes.IStream,System.Int64,System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Copies a specified number of bytes from the current seek pointer in the stream to the current seek pointer in another stream.
member.param: A reference to the destination stream.
The number of bytes to copy from the source stream.
On successful return, contains the actual number of bytes read from the source. Note: the native signature is to a ULARGE_INTEGER*, so 64 bits are written to this parameter on success.
On successful return, contains the actual number of bytes written to the destination. Note: the native signature is to a ULARGE_INTEGER*, so 64 bits are written to this parameter on success.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Windows.Shell.ManagedIStream.LockRegion(System.Int64,System.Int64,System.Int32)
member.summary: Restricts access to a specified range of bytes in the stream.
member.param: The byte offset for the beginning of the range.
The length of the range, in bytes, to restrict.
The requested restrictions on accessing the range.
member.remarks: For more information, see the existing documentation for IStream::LockRegion in the MSDN library. This class does not implement LockRegion. A COMException is thrown if it is used.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Windows.Shell.ManagedIStream.Read(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Reads a specified number of bytes from the stream object into memory starting at the current seek pointer.
member.param: When this method returns, contains the data read from the stream. This parameter is passed uninitialized.
The number of bytes to read from the stream object.
A pointer to a ULONG variable that receives the actual number of bytes read from the stream object.
member.remarks: For more information, see the existing documentation for ISequentialStream::Read in the MSDN library.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Windows.Shell.ManagedIStream.Revert
member.summary: Discards all changes that have been made to a transacted stream since the last Commit call.
member.remarks: This class does not implement Revert. A COMException is thrown if it is used.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Windows.Shell.ManagedIStream.Seek(System.Int64,System.Int32,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Changes the seek pointer to a new location relative to the beginning of the stream, to the end of the stream, or to the current seek pointer.
member.param: The displacement to add to dwOrigin.
The origin of the seek. The origin can be the beginning of the file, the current seek pointer, or the end of the file.

On successful return, contains the offset of the seek pointer from the beginning of the stream. Note: the native signature is to a ULARGE_INTEGER*, so 64 bits are written to this parameter on success.
member.remarks: For more information, see the existing documentation for IStream::Seek in the MSDN library.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Windows.Shell.ManagedIStream.SetSize(System.Int64)
member.summary: Changes the size of the stream object.
member.param: The new size of the stream as a number of bytes.
member.remarks: For more information, see the existing documentation for IStream::SetSize in the MSDN library.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Windows.Shell.ManagedIStream.Stat(System.Runtime.InteropServices.ComTypes.STATSTG@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Retrieves the STATSTG structure for this stream.
member.param: When this method returns, it contains a STATSTG structure that describes this stream object. This parameter is passed uninitialized.
Members in the STATSTG structure that this method does not return, thus saving some memory allocation operations.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Windows.Shell.ManagedIStream.UnlockRegion(System.Int64,System.Int64,System.Int32)
member.summary: Removes the access restriction on a range of bytes previously restricted with the LockRegion method.
member.param: The byte offset for the beginning of the range.
The length, in bytes, of the range to restrict.
The access restrictions previously placed on the range.
member.remarks: For more information, see the existing documentation for IStream::UnlockRegion in the MSDN library. This class doesn't implement UnlockRegion. A COMException is thrown if it is used.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Windows.Shell.ManagedIStream.Write(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Writes a specified number of bytes into the stream object starting at the current seek pointer.
member.param: The buffer to write this stream to.
The number of bytes to write to the stream.
On successful return, contains the actual number of bytes written to the stream object. If the caller sets this pointer to null, this method does not provide the actual number of bytes written.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Windows.Shell.ManagedIStream.Dispose
member.summary: Releases resources controlled by this object.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Windows.Shell.SFGAO.CANLINK
member.summary: Objects can be linked
member.remarks:
DROPEFFECT_LINK.
If this bit is set on an item in the shell folder, a 'Create Shortcut' menu item will be added to the File menu and context menus for the item. If the user selects that command, your IContextMenu::InvokeCommand() will be called with 'link'. That flag will also be used to determine if 'Create Shortcut' should be added when the item in your folder is dragged to another folder.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Windows.Shell.STR_GPS
member.summary: STR_GPS_*
member.remarks:
When requesting a property store through IShellFolder, you can specify the equivalent of GPS_DEFAULT by passing in a null IBindCtx parameter.
You can specify the equivalent of GPS_READWRITE by passing a mode of STGM_READWRITE | STGM_EXCLUSIVE in the bind context
Here are the string versions of GPS_ flags, passed to IShellFolder::BindToObject() via IBindCtx::RegisterObjectParam() These flags are valid when requesting an IPropertySetStorage or IPropertyStore handler
The meaning of these flags are described above.
There is no STR_ equivalent for GPS_TEMPORARY because temporary property stores are provided by IShellItem2 only -- not by the underlying IShellFolder.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Windows.Shell.ITaskbarList2.MarkFullscreenWindow(System.IntPtr,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Marks a window as full-screen.
member.param: The handle of the window to be marked.
A Boolean value marking the desired full-screen status of the window.
member.remarks: Setting the value of fFullscreen to true, the Shell treats this window as a full-screen window, and the taskbar is moved to the bottom of the z-order when this window is active. Setting the value of fFullscreen to false removes the full-screen marking, but does not cause the Shell to treat the window as though it were definitely not full-screen. With a false fFullscreen value, the Shell depends on its automatic detection facility to specify how the window should be treated, possibly still flagging the window as full-screen.

member.name: T:Bloomberglp.AppPortalApi.Desktop.Clipboard
member.summary: Provides access to the system clipboard for data storage/retrieval and a set of data formats.

member.name: M:Bloomberglp.AppPortalApi.Desktop.Clipboard.GetData(System.String)
member.summary: Retrieves data in a specified format from the Clipboard.
member.param: The string that specifies the format of the data to retrieve.
member.returns: An object that contains the data in the specified format, or null if the data is unavailable in the specified format.
member.exception: format is null
The caller does not have permission to get the clipboard data in the given format.

member.name: M:Bloomberglp.AppPortalApi.Desktop.Clipboard.SetData(System.String,System.Object)
member.summary: Stores the specified data on the Clipboard in the specified format.
member.param: The string that specifies the format to use to store the data.
An object representing the data to store on the Clipboard.
member.remarks: This method adds data with auto-conversion enabled if the corresponding data format is FileDrop or Bitmap. Otherwise, auto-conversion is disabled.
member.exception: The caller does not have permission to set the clipboard data in the given format.

member.name: M:Bloomberglp.AppPortalApi.Desktop.Clipboard.ContainsData(System.String)
member.summary: Queries the Clipboard for the presence of data in a specified data format.
member.param: The format of the data to look for.
member.returns: true if data in the specified format is available on the Clipboard; otherwise, false. See Remarks.
member.remarks: A query for the data format Bitmap or FileDrop will return true if the data can be automatically converted to the specified data format. For other data formats, this method returns true only if the specified format is available natively on the Clipboard.
member.exception: format is null
The caller does not have permission to query the clipboard for the given format.

member.name: M:Bloomberglp.AppPortalApi.Desktop.Clipboard.IsFormatValid(System.String)
member.summary: Checks if format is recognized by the API.
member.param: The string that specifies the format to validate.

list.item: true - string is recognized as a clipboard format name
false - string represents invalid name of clipboard format

member.name: T:Bloomberglp.AppPortalApi.Data.Sql.DbException
member.summary: The exception that is thrown when the database returns a warning or error. This class cannot be inherited.

remarks.para: This class is created whenever the .NET Framework Data Provider for AppPortal database encounters an error generated from the database.

The following is general information on handling exceptions. Your code should catch exceptions to prevent the application from crashing and to allow displaying a relevant error message to the user. You can use database transactions to ensure that the data is consistent regardless of what happens in the client application (including a crash). Features like System.Transaction. TransactionScope or the BeginTransaction method ensure consistent data regardless of exceptions raised by a provider. Transactions can fail so catch failures and retry the transaction.

In addition to the provider-specific errors, .NET Framework data provider types can raise .NET Framework exceptions such as System.OutOfMemoryException and System.Threading.ThreadAbortException. Recovery from these exceptions may not be possible.

Bad input can cause a .NET Framework data provider type to raise an exception such as System.ArgumentException or System.IndexOutOfRangeException. Calling a method at the wrong time can raise System.InvalidOperationException.

member.name: M:Bloomberglp.AppPortalApi.Desktop.AppPortalToolTipService.Register
member.summary: Intercept ToolTipService.FindToolTip RoutedEvent. This will give us the chance to replace built-in PopupControlService with PortalPopupControlService

member.name: M:Bloomberglp.AppPortalApi.Desktop.AppPortalToolTipService.UnRegisterToolTipService
member.summary: This code is extemely hacky. The purpose is to remove ToolTipService.OnFindToolTip from FindToolTipEvent's handlers list so that AppPortalToolTipService becomes the only handler of that event. This makes sure ToolTipService doesn't call into PopupControlService. This method is .NET version dependent. So far it works on .NET 3.5 SP1 and .NET 4.

member.name: M:Bloomberglp.AppPortalApi.Desktop.AppPortalToolTipService.OnFindToolTip(System.Object,System.Windows.RoutedEventArgs)
member.summary: This is called when FindToolTipEvent is raised from AppPortalPopupControlService or PopupControlService. Here when the closest element with ToolTip is found, we intentionally set TargetElement and KeepCurrentActive to cheat on PopupControlService so that it thinks there's no ToolTip. Thus no ToolTip will be opened by PopupControlService. In order fo AppPortalPopupControlService to open ToolTips, we transfer TargetElement and KeepCurrentActive to FindToolTipResultTable. They act like Attacned Properties on RoutedEventArgs. This method is dependent on .NET version. So far it works on .NET 3.5 SP1 and .NET 4.

member.summary: Creates an object capable of opening a document in an external viewer.

list.item: Documents are identified by URLs.
The API uses the terminal's communication channels to access information from Internet.
No query string or URL fragments are allowed in the URL.
There are constraints on communication protocols and content types:

remarks.para:
Allowed content types:
application/pdfPDF Document
application/rtfRich Text Format file
text/plainPlain Text
image/gifGIF image file
image/jpegJPEG image file
image/x-pngPNG image

Allowed protocols:
http://HTTP Protocol
https://HTTPS Protocol

Allowed file extensions in URLs:
.pdf, .rtf, .txt, .gif, .jpg, .png

member.summary: Open document in external viewer.
member.param: URL of the document.
member.remarks:
Before file is downloaded:
The URL is validated for permitted protocols. Currently only the HTTP and HTTPS are allowed. When file is received the following is performed before function returns:
Content type is validated.
File is saved locally with appropriate file extension derived from content type.
Control is transferred to Windows shell to open this document with default program, registered for the extension.
member.exception: Provides exception reason and internal error codes
Commonly thrown when the document is already open in another window.

member.name: T:Bloomberglp.AppPortalApi.DataPersistence.NamespaceDoc
member.summary:
This namespace contains the API to persist application's configuration/state data.
Serialized data is saved on network and can be reused by terminal sessions on different computers for the same user.

member.name: T:Bloomberglp.AppPortalApi.DataPersistence.PersistenceService
member.summary: Public facade for the Persistence API.

remarks.para:
Serialized data is internally identified by Object ID, Context name, Bloomberg's internal vendor id, and logged (terminal) user ID. The vendor ID and user ID are injected by infrastructure in the cloud.
Object ID The unique identifier of data blob within a given namespace.
Context A logical container that provides context for the Object IDs. Same object ID can exist in different contexts. Use your company name as the prefix for a context name.
Default context Internal application id is used as the context name.

The persistence API provides one way to save data and two ways to retrieve data.
Save data
Strong type serialization Object can be serialized (deep copy) only by providing strong typed object reference. See > for details.
Get data
Strong type de-serialization A new instance of the type is created by de-serialization process. See for details.
Plain text De-serialized as JSON into string. See .

Data serialization rules.
Root object's (the one that is passed to ) type can only derive from or
Types of serialized property or field can be only of the following: primitive types, nested types of root type; array, list, dictionary of primitive types or root's nested classes.
What is getting serialized. By default public fields and properties (POCOs - plain old CLR objects). It can customized by using WCF data contract serializer attributes. Types Supported by the Data Contract Serializer (http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms731923.aspx).
Data contract versioning.
This implementation supports guidelines from MSDN's "Versioning When Schema Validation Is Not Required" (http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms733832.aspx).
Basic rules:

list.item: Do not change properties/fields names.
Do not change properties/fields types.
Do not delete properties/fields.
Do not attempt to version data contracts by type inheritance.

Starting with the first version of a data contract, always inherit from to enable round-tripping. implements IExtensibleDataObject interface. See "Forward-Compatible Data Contracts" (http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms731083.aspx)

member.name: F:Bloomberglp.AppPortalApi.DataPersistence.PersistenceService.DefaultContext
member.summary: Default context is set to internal Application Portal's application ID

member.param: context name
member.returns: A context object. It is used to save and get data.
member.remarks: It is a good practice to use organization/department names as prefixes to context name.

member.summary: The minimum value for Coordinated Universal Time (UTC), which is used to initialize all variables. Otherwise, the JSON serializer will fail for zone >= GMT + 1.

Instead, initialize DataTime members with MinValueUtc.

member.name: T:Bloomberglp.AppPortalApi.DataPersistence.DataElementExtensions
member.summary: Extension methods for DataElement type.

remarks.para: Advantage of extension methods - it is possible to return null instead of throwing an exception when invoked with a null object. This is not possible to do when the function is implemented as a member of a class.

This type provides two sets of methods to manipulate de-serialized data:
Data mapping functions Get data when structure of saved data is known. Functions: (Item, ToList, ToArray, ToDictionary)
Data iteration functions Iterate trough data when the data layout is unknown. Functions: ComplexUnnamedValues, SimpleUnnamedValues, ComplexNnamedValues, SimpleNnamedValues. There is a sample for the intended use of this functionality in an example section It is important to understand key differences between these functions. The result of "Complex" functions can be iterated for values of a value from the result. "Simple" result elements cannot be queried for inner values. There are two type of internal storage containers: list - "Unnamed values" and dictionary = "Named values".

member.name: T:Bloomberglp.AppPortalApi.Data.Sql.NamespaceDoc
member.summary:
This is an implementation of ADO.NET interfaces for AppPortal's local database. In addition to exposing ADO.Net interfaces, objects and factories it does the following:
Uses database logical names instead of actual file names (it is not possible to specify custom database file locations).
Enforces database naming conventions.
Uses Application Portals logging as default log provider for SQLite log messages.
